importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Combs was arrested in September 2024, marking the beginning of a high-profile legal case that drew global media attention.
The sentencing hearing occurred in September 2025, during which Combs expressed remorse and requested a lighter sentence.
The appeal notice was filed on October 21, 2025, signaling ongoing legal challenges to the conviction and sentence.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The nearly two-month trial that took place in the summer of 2025, spanning from late 2024 to early 2025, was central to the case's development and global media coverage.

keyTakeAways: Sean 'Diddy' Combs, a prominent music industry figure, has been convicted of two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution and sentenced to 50 months in prison.
Combs was acquitted on charges of sex trafficking and racketeering, indicating a split in jury verdicts on the severity of his alleged actions.
Judge Arun Subramanian imposed a $500,000 fine and five years of probation, emphasizing accountability for abuse of women.
Combs expressed regret during sentencing, acknowledging his actions as 'disgusting, shameful, and sick', and apologized to two women who testified against him.
His legal team has announced plans to appeal both the conviction and the sentence, signaling significant legal and public interest in the outcome.

The case involved allegations that Combs used his influence in the music industry to coerce women into participating in 'freak-offs' with male escorts, centered on his relationship with Cassandra Ventura and a woman identified as Jane.
The case drew international media attention due to its implications for power, consent, and abuse in high-profile relationships.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean 'Diddy' Combs, a globally influential music mogul, has been convicted of two counts of transporting individuals to engage in prostitution and sentenced to 50 months in prison. While acquitted on more serious charges of sex trafficking and racketeering, the conviction centers on allegations that he exploited his power to coerce women—particularly through 'freak-offs' involving his girlfriend Cassandra Ventura and another woman, Jane—into participating in sexual encounters. The judge, Arun Subramanian, emphasized accountability for abuse of women, imposing a $500,000 fine and five years of probation. Combs expressed remorse, apologized to the women involved, and requested mercy, but his legal team has now announced plans to appeal both the conviction and the sentence, reflecting ongoing public and legal scrutiny of power dynamics, consent, and accountability in celebrity culture.
title: Sean 'Diddy' Combs says he plans to appeal sentence and conviction
